docTitle.titlePart:
Ionized physical vapor deposition (IPVD):
Magnetron sputtering discharges

byline.affiliation: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Iceland,

front.div:
Abstract. Over the past decade, various magnetron sputtering techniques have appeared
that provide a high degree of ionization of the sputtered vapor. Here, ionized physical vapor
deposition (IPVD) magnetron sputtering systems are reviewed. The application of a secondary
discharge to a magnetron sputtering discharge, either an inductively coupled plasma source
(ICP-MS) or a microwave amplified magnetron sputtering, is currently widely used. High power
impulse magnetron sputtering (HiPIMS) is a sputtering technique where a high density plasma
is created by applying high power pulses at low frequency and low duty cycle to a magnetron
sputtering device. Other methods such as the self-sustained sputtering (SSS), and the hollow
cathode magnetron (HCM) are discussed as well. Essential to these methods is a high electron
density which leads to a high degree of ionization of the sputtered vapor.
